                        <gco:CharacterString/>                      </gmd:name>                      <gmd:issueIdentification>                         <gco:CharacterString/>                      </gmd:issueIdentification>                   </gmd:CI_Series>                </gmd:series>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>The Map of the Elevation of the Bedrock Surface in Iowa was compiled using all available data, principally information from GEOSAM, supplemented with well and boring information from the Iowa DOT, exposure reports from Iowa Geological & Water Survey reports and files, and the Department of Soil Conservation county soils maps for Iowa. The soils maps were especially valuable, since they identified soils that encountered bedrock within the soil horizon, and less dependably also spot-located rock exposures. A 50 foot contour interval was chosen for the map because it was considered to best represent the accuracy of the well data, allowed for fairly good representation of the bedrock surface in areas with limited well control, and was mappable in high relief areas (the contours packed so close together that it precluded mapping or forced the software to snap-join contours). The 50 foot contour interval also allowed areas where bedrock was present within the soil horizon (2-3 feet) to be treated as areas of exposures. In these areas the bedrock elevation was mapped as only slightly below the surface elevation, so contours on the 7\ufffd\ufffd' topographic maps were closely followed in mapping the bedrock elevation. Consequently, on the completed map of bedrock elevation, these areas display much more contorted and crenulated contour lines than the areas where only drill control was utilized. This allows the user a general feeling for the accuracy of the map; the more crenulated the contours, the more control was available for the mapping, and the more accurate is the mapping.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>This digital, geographically referenced data set was developed by the Iowa Department of Natural Resources to carry out agency responsibilities related to management, protection, and development of Iowa's natural resources.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:credit>             <gco:CharacterString>Recognized for significant contributions to the maps production: Bill J. Bunker, James D. Giglierano, Greg A. Ludvigson, Robert M. McKay, Huaibao P. Liu, and Thomas R. Marshall. Supported by the US Geogican Survey and the National Cooperative Geologic Mapping Program.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:credit>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode"                                  codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>          </gmd:status>          <gmd:pointOfContact>             <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                <gmd:organisationName>                   <gco:CharacterString>Iowa Geological and Water Survey, DNR</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:organisationName>                <gmd:positionName>                   <gco:CharacterString>Geologist</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:positionName>                <gmd:contactInfo>                   <gmd:CI_Contact>                      <gmd:phone>                         <gmd:CI_Telephone>                            <gmd:voice>                               <gco:CharacterString>319-335-1575</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:voice>                         </gmd:CI_Telephone>                      </gmd:phone>                      <gmd:hoursOfService>                         <gco:CharacterString>8:00 AM - 4:30 PM Monday - Friday</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:hoursOfService>                      <gmd:contactInstructions>                         <gco:CharacterString>Brian J.         </gmd:report>          <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>PRODUCTION OF THE MAP OF THE ELEVATION OF THE BEDROCK SURFACE IN IOWA: The newly compiled bedrock topographic map of Iowa incorporates extensive data sources from published and unpublished sources archived at the Iowa Geological & Water Survey (IGWS). Mapping in some areas of Iowa, where feasible, was completed on 7-1/2 minute (1:24,000) topographic quadrangle maps (U.S. Geological Survey). Elsewhere, bedrock outcrop information was compiled at a 1:100,000 scale on the various county topographic maps (U.S. Geological Survey). In regions of extensive Quaternary cover, information on the bedrock topography was derived largely from extensive subsurface well data archived at the IGWS Oakdale Rock Library & Research Facility. Stratigraphic information for virtually all bedrock exposures in Iowa are available in archived files and field notes, and include descriptions of the natural exposures, roadcuts, and quarries. Well logs provide lithologic information derived from descriptions of well cuttings (generally at 5 foot sample intervals), tied to surface elevation, to produce files of color-coded striplogs with lithologic descriptions and interpretations of the lithostratigraphy. Well logs provide lithologic information derived from descriptions of well cuttings (generally at 5 foot sample intervals), tied to surface elevation, to produce files of color-coded striplogs with lithologic descriptions and interpretations of the lithostratigraphy. All existing well logs were examined and systematically re-evaluated for bedrock surface and stratigraphy as part of this mapping process. This involved the support of numerous Research Assistants (graduate students from the University of Iowa, Department of Geoscience) over the years working in cooperation with IGWS staff. Various drillers' logs and other well penetrations that lack detailed logs were used to supplement and refine interpretations of the bedrock topography and stratigraphy where possible. Detailed county soil surveys prepared by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, have mapped soil series and bedrock exposure at a 1:15,840 scale. Soil descriptions for each county were examined and soils that encountered bedrock within the soil horizon were identified. The soil data was filtered for those soils encountering bedrock and those areas covered by these polygons represent areas of shallow-to-bedrock soils and the coverages were saved as ArcGis shapefiles. Finally, maps of bedrock elevation from adjoining states were obtained and georeferenced in order to make the new maps match existing maps where possible.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>9999-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:processor>                         <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                            <gmd:organisationName>                               <gco:CharacterString>Iowa Geological & Water Survey, <gco:CharacterString>Geologist</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:positionName>                            <gmd:contactInfo>                               <gmd:CI_Contact> </gmd:phone>                                  <gmd:contactInstructions>                                     <gco:CharacterString>Ray Anderson [Raymond.Anderson@dnr.iowa.gov] Brian Witzke [Brian.Witzke@dnr.iowa.gov] Bill Bunker [Bill.Bunker@dnr.iowa.gov]</gco:CharacterString>                                  </gmd:contactInstructions>                               </gmd:CI_Contact>                            </gmd:contactInfo>                            <gmd:role>                               <gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList="http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/metadata/published/xsd/schema/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode" </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>MAPPING OF THE BEDROCK SURFACE ELEVATION: When most of the digital database was assembled, work began on mapping of the elevation of the bedrock surface. All bedrock elevation mapping was done using ArcGis (ERSI) software. Since mapping was at a 50 foot contour interval, the areas of shallow-to-bedrock soils (bedrock less than 24 inches) were considered to be exposures for mapping purposes. Georeferenced U.S.G.S. 7-1/2 minute topographic quadrangle maps of the area being mapped were loaded into the ArcGis project and white background and green forested areas on the maps were rendered transparent. When mapping in the areas of the shallow-to-bedrock polygons, the bedrock elevation contours were drawn directly on surface contour lines of the 7-1/2 minute quadrangle maps through these polygons and then continued into areas of higher surface elevation between closely-spaced polygons. In areas with no shallow-to-bedrock polygons GEOSAM well data was utilized to control location of the bedrock elevation contours. Proximity of shallow to bedrock soil polygons to the area being mapped were also used as an indicator of bedrock depth. Even if the polygon did not intersect a 50-foot contour being mapped, it still provided a close estimate of bedrock depth in its area. Using these data to control location of contour lines the elevation of the bedrock surface was contoured by an IGWS staff geologist. The lines were drawn to be consistent with observed patterns and characteristics of stream incision into geologic materials at the land surface. Where possible, contours were joined at map edges to current bedrock elevation maps from adjoining areas or states. In areas of limited control contours were spaced at equal distances from one another based upon bedrock elevations of available well points. In areas of high control density, such as areas of shallow-to bedrock soils, the contours are very crenulated and complex, whereas in areas of only sparse well control the contours are more smooth and flowing. This allows the map user to tell at a glance how much control was present in any given area and therefore the accuracy of the map's representation of the true bedrock surface elevation in that area. In other words, areas of complex contours imply areas of higher map reliability than areas of smooth flowing contours.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>9999-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:processor>                         <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                            <gmd:organisationName>                               <gco:CharacterString>Iowa Geological & Water Survey, DNR</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:organisationName>                            <gmd:positionName>                               <gco:CharacterString>Geologist</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:positionName>                            <gmd:contactInfo>                               <gmd:CI_Contact>                                  <gmd:phone>                                     <gmd:CI_Telephone>                                        <gmd:voice>                                           <gco:CharacterString>319-335-1575</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:voice>                                     </gmd:CI_Telephone>                                  </gmd:phone>                                  <gmd:contactInstructions>                                     <gco:CharacterString>Brian Witzke [Brian.Witzke@dnr.iowa.gov] Raymond R.
